title: If you spend half your wage within 48 hours you are not alone
text:
Many of us regret the payday spending (Picture: Getty)

On payday it is very difficult to resist the urge to go on a shopping spree or get a few extra rounds in at the pub.

If this sounds like you, it turns out you are not alone because a fifth of workers spend more than half of their monthly salary within 48 hours of it landing in their accounts.

According to a Nationwide Building Society survey, 22 per cent of people polled said more than half of their spending money – excluding bills and essential items – is gone within the first two days of being paid.

Six in 10 said there is less than £100 in their accounts the week before payday – ouch – and 15 per cent said they have no money whatsoever at the end of the month.

More than half (55 per cent) said they are more likely to splash out on unusual purchases within a week of getting paid.

The survey, which asked more than 4,000 people about their spending habits, found big food shops were where most (27 per cent) saw their hard-earned cash go on payday.

Unsurprisingly, food dominates the top of the spending charts, with getting a takeaway coming in second at 24 per cent, and eating in a nice restaurant in fourth place.

Most run out of money before the end of the month (Picture: Getty)

The third most common thing for earners to treat themselves with was new clothes.

The poll found that nearly two-thirds of earners ‘bookmark’ items to buy in the weeks leading to payday so they’re ready to splash the cash once their account looks more healthy.

But nine in 10 who made impulse buys regret it, while two-fifths of 16 to 24-year-olds admitted their spending habits are influenced by celebrities.

Nationwide has a campaign called PayDay SaveDay to encourage people to consider saving a bit more money on the day they get paid.

Gemma Pauley, head of PayDay SaveDay, said: ‘It’s clear that the temptation to spend like a rock star come payday is very common.

‘And why not? We all feel that we deserve a treat when we get paid. But how much of that is due to penny-pinching towards the end of the month due to overspending?’

The 10 most popular things people splurge on after payday 1. Larger-than-usual food shop, 27% 2. Getting a takeaway, 24% 3. Buying new clothes, 20% 4. Eating out at a restaurant, 16% 5. Buying new items for my home, 14% 6. Going to the pub, 12% 7. Buying gifts for family members, 11% =8. Buying event tickets, 10% =8. Buying toys for my children, 10% =8. Getting a nice lunch at work, 10%
